did.abstract: Edith S. Lisansky Gomberg was a professor and researcher in psychology and social work with special interest and expertise in the areas of alcohol problems and drug abuse in women. Gomberg's papers detail her active professional life as a researcher and professor with material on her research and teaching, publications, presentations, material documenting her various activities and involvement in her areas of interest, as well as correspondence and biographical information.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The records were donated by Judith Lisansky (donor no. 9661) in September 2005.

accessrestrict.p: The Edith Gomberg papers are open for research except for certain records restricted by statute or university policy. Restricted material includes personnel-related files, including search, review, promotion, and tenure files; student educational records; client/patient records; and records of executive officers of the university.

The Gomberg papers include restricted material in the following categories:
Patient/Client Records -- Boxes 7, 12-23

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Edith Gomberg Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Edith Silverglied Lisansky Gomberg was a professor and researcher in psychology and social work with special interest and expertise in the areas of alcohol problems and drug abuse in women. She received her B.A. in Psychology at Brooklyn College in 1938, her Masters at Columbia University in 1940 and her Ph.D. at Yale in 1949. She has taught at several institutions including Yale, University of Puerto Rico and the University of Michigan.

She began her career at the University of Michigan in 1974 as a Professor in the School of Social Work. Since then, she held a number of different positions in various units of the University including a research scientist at the Institute of Gerontology, Faculty Associate at the Institute for Social Research, Associate Director of the Clinical Research Training in Alcoholism at the Alcohol Research Center, and Professor of Psychology in the Department of Psychiatry.

Her curriculum vitae (1999) cites "alcohol and drug studies," "gender and deviant behavior," "adaptation of the elderly: drugs, alcohol, gender differences," and "ethnicity and race issues," as her fields of interest and expertise. She is well-known and widely published and was often called upon for her expertise in the subject area. She was asked to speak often at many conferences, served on committees and boards, consulted on several research projects, and reviewed many publications.
Gomberg passed away on January 9, 2005 in Ann Arbor. Additional information on Edith's professional and personal life can be found on a website created by her family at http://www.edithgomberg.com

scopecontent.p: Th Edith Gomberg papers detail her active professional life as a researcher and professor with material on her research and teaching, publications, presentations, material documenting her various activities and involvement in her areas of interest, as well as correspondence and biographical information. Gomberg's papers contain the following series: Biographical, Activities/Involvement, Correspondence, Personnel, Presentations, Teaching material, Publications, Research, and Audiovisual Material.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan. School of Social Work.

scopecontent.p: The Biographical Series (0.25 linear ft.) contains a small amount of information on Gomberg including her curriculum vitae, abstracts and memorabilia.

scopecontent.p: The Activities/Involvement series (0.75 linear ft., 1964-1999) can provide researchers an idea of Gomberg's involvement in the areas of alcohol and drug abuse in.

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series (0.3 linear ft., 1958-1997) includes chronological as well as topical correspondence detailing Gomberg's professional as well as personal life.

The Presentations series (1.5 linear ft., 1959-1999) contains notes, outlines, drafts, and programs from Gomberg's many presentations to organizations, professional conferences, as well as seminars and workshops. The series has been arranged by organization and event. The finding aid details Gomberg's specific presentation topic for each event.

scopecontent.p: Teaching Material (1 linear ft., 1961, 1975-1998) primarily includes teaching material while Gomberg was Professor in the School of Social Work from 1974 to 1990 and Adjunct Professor from 1993 to 1998. Teaching materials include syllabi, tests, as well as notes and outlines.

scopecontent.p: The Publications series (1.5 linear ft., 1948-2003) contains some of Gomberg's published materials as well as drafts and correspondence of publications.

scopecontent.p: Gomberg's Research files (11 linear ft., 1940-2003) make up the bulk of materials in the collection. The research series documents Gomberg's various research interests, including various grants, ideas of projects, notes and outlines, as well as raw data, reviews of results, and preparation materials. Gomberg's early research, not necessarily alcohol and drug-related, conducted while at Columbia and Yale has also been included.

The most detailed research files cover one of Gomberg's largest research projects on Alcoholism in Women studies. These studies on alcoholism in women began as a three year project from 1980 to 1983 and was then extended until 1985. This project included a detailed interview of over 1000 women on their personal background as well as their alcohol and substance abuse history. Materials include grant proposals, funding requests, data, and interview questionnaire drafts. Also included are 11 feet of the actual completed questionnaires (restricted for 100 years). Researchers may also want to consult Gomberg's teaching materials for her Social Work 705/614 course on psychological testing and social work practice, which overlapped with this study during a few years and may give some insight into the methodology of this particular research and interview process.

scopecontent.p: The Audiovisual Material (0.3 linear ft., 1977-1988 and undated) contains photographs and audiocassettes. Researchers will find photographs of Gomberg with various individuals as well as group photos of the Department of Psychiatry and the Alcohol Research Center at the University of Michigan. Audiocassettes cover Gomberg's research, with topics detailed in the finding aid.
